title: Treatment of Mild Cognitive Impairment With Transcutaneous Vagal Nerve Stimulation
description_brief: Patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (MCI) often have compromised quality of life (QOL). Cognitive impairment is a major contributor to decrements in QOL and progression of MCI often leads to loss of independence and withdrawal from social participation. MCI, in many patients, is an early expression of neurodegenerative disease. Patients with MCI frequently convert to Alzheimer's disease (AD) (12-16 percent by some estimates per year). Treatments for MCI are of limited scope and availability and of limited effectiveness. Thus, there is great need for treatments that can improve cognition and extend QOL in patients with MCI. The investigators propose to investigate the effect of a non-invasive and safe intervention that should have direct influence on brain systems underlying AD, transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation (tVNS).
description_detailed:
Patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (MCI) often have compromised quality of life (QOL). Cognitive impairment is a major contributor to decrements in QOL and progression of MCI often leads to loss of independence and withdrawal from social participation. MCI, in many patients, is an early expression of neurodegenerative disease. Patients with MCI frequently convert to Alzheimer's disease (AD) (12-16 percent by some estimates per year). Treatments for MCI are of limited scope and availability and of limited effectiveness. Thus, there is great need for treatments that can improve cognition and extend QOL in patients with MCI. The investigators propose to investigate the effect of a non-invasive and safe intervention that should have direct influence on brain systems underlying AD, transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation (tVNS). Transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation (tVNS) may ameliorate symptoms of MCI. The investigators have demonstrated, in patients with epilepsy, that VNS improves memory; however, tVNS has not been used to treat patients with MCI. tVNS can now be performed without surgery by transcutaneous stimulation of the auricular branch with electrodes on the external ear. tVNS has the potential to improve cognition and may even alter the course of decline in patients with MCI. The investigators will employ a multimodal MRI-based neuroimaging approach combined with comprehensive and targeted cognitive testing to assess changes with tVNS in cognition in patients with MCI.

The investigators will evaluate the effects of tVNS on patients who have been diagnosed with MCI as well as healthy older controls. Very little in the way of mechanistic data or understanding of individual differences in response to tVNS in MCI/AD has been published. Thus, this is a necessary study to evaluate the potential utility of tVNS to enhance cognitive performance in patients with MCI. These data may serve as a platform for supporting the development of a clinical treatment trial with this technology.

groups.title: Sham First, Then tVNS
groups.description:
This group will receive sham stimulation, initially. Participants will be randomized between the two arms of the crossover sessions (tVNS first, then sham vs. sham first, then tVNS). Behavioral portions of the testing will then be carried out twice, with at least 72 hours between sessions (to avoid carryover effects).

Transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation: Non-invasive stimulation provided by transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation device at 20Hz, 100 μs pulse width

Sham stimulation: Sham stimulation will be performed using electrodes placed on earlobe

groups.title: tVNS First, Then Sham
groups.description:
This group will receive transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation, initially. Participants will be randomized between the two arms of the crossover sessions (tVNS first, then sham vs. sham first, then tVNS). Behavioral portions of the testing will then be carried out twice, with at least 72 hours between sessions (to avoid carryover effects).

Transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation: Non-invasive stimulation provided by transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation device at 20Hz, 100 μs pulse width

Sham stimulation: Sham stimulation will be performed using electrodes placed on earlobe

groups.title: Initial Sham
groups.description:
This group will receive sham stimulation, initially. Participants will be randomized between the two arms of the crossover sessions (initial tVNS vs. initial Sham). Behavioral portions of the testing will then be carried out twice, with at least 72 hours between sessions (to avoid carryover effects).

Transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation: Non-invasive stimulation provided by transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation device at 20Hz, 100 μs pulse width

Sham stimulation: Sham stimulation will be performed using electrodes placed on earlobe

groups.title: Initial tVNS
groups.description:
This group will receive transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation, initially. Participants will be randomized between the two arms of the crossover sessions (initial tVNS vs. initial Sham). Behavioral portions of the testing will then be carried out twice, with at least 72 hours between sessions (to avoid carryover effects).

Transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation: Non-invasive stimulation provided by transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation device at 20Hz, 100 μs pulse width

Sham stimulation: Sham stimulation will be performed using electrodes placed on earlobe

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Wechsler Test of Adult Reading (standard score)
measures.description: The Wechsler Test of Adult Reading (WTAR) uses vocabulary level to estimate an individual's level of functioning before the onset of injury or illness. The raw score of the WTAR (0 worst, 50 best) is converted to a standard score (50-134), which is then used to predict full-scale IQ.

measures.title: Beck Depression Inventory-2
measures.description: The Beck Depression Inventory-2 (BDI-II) is a 21-item self-report inventory measuring the severity of depression symptoms over the past two weeks. A total score of 0-9 indicates minimal symptoms,10-18 indicates mild symptoms, 19-29 indicates moderate symptoms, and 30-63 indicates severe symptoms.

measures.title: Clinical Dementia Rating Scale (sum of boxes)
measures.description: The Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) Scale is an assessment to stage severity of dementia. Cognitive functioning is rated on a 5 point scale (0 no impairment, 0.5 questionable impairment, 1 mild, 2 moderate, 3 severe) across 6 domains: memory, orientation, judgement \& problem solving, community affairs, home \& hobbies, and personal care. The CDR-some of boxes score (SOB) is obtained by summing each of the domain scores, with scores ranging from 0 to 18. Participants in the study must obtain a SOB of 0.5-4 to meet criteria for MCI diagnosis and qualify for the study.

measures.title: Functional Activities Questionnaire
measures.description: The functional activities questionnaire (FAQ) is a 10-item screening tool for evaluating independence in instrumental activities for daily living. Sum of scores range 0 (fully independent) to 30 (fully dependent), and a cut-point of 9 is used to indicate impaired functioning.

measures.title: Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (total immediate recall)
measures.description: The Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT-R) is a verbal learning and memory task with a 12-item word list learned over 3 trials. The total immediate recall score is the sum of correct words recalled after each of the 3 learning trials, which can range from 0 to 36.

measures.title: Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (total delayed recall)
measures.description: The Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT-R) is a verbal learning and memory task with a 12-item word list learned over 3 trials. The total delayed recall score is the number of total correct words recalled (ranging from 0 to 12) after a 20-25 minute delay.

measures.title: Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (total retention)
measures.description: The Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT-R) is a verbal learning and memory task with a 12-item word list learned over 3 trials. The total retention score is calculated by dividing the total delayed recall score by the higher score of learning trial 2 or 3, and multiplying this by 100, to provide the percentage of words retained following the 20-25 minute delay.

measures.title: Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (recognition)
measures.description: The Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT-R) is a verbal learning and memory task with a 12-item word list learned over 3 trials. Within the delayed yes-no recognition part of the task, the participant is presented with a larger list or words and responds to whether each was on the original 12-item list. The recognition discrimination index score is calculated as number of hits (correctly identified words from the list) - number of false positive words (incorrectly identified words that were not on the list), with scores ranging from 0 to 12 (perfect score).

outcomeMeasures.title: Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (Total Delayed Recall)
outcomeMeasures.description: The Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (RAVLT) is a verbal learning and memory task with a 15-item word list learned over 5 trials. The total delayed recall score is the number of total correct words recalled (ranging from 0 to 15) after a 30 minute delay.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: As a crossover design, each participant operated as their own control. Therefore results of data analysis are presented per intervention (i.e., tVNS vs. Sham) rather than per arm (i.e., first tVNS, then Sham, etc.).
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: 30 minutes after administration of 5 list learning trials; 2 minutes to complete delayed recall of word-list

groups.title: Sham
groups.description:
This is the sham arm for all participants.

Sham stimulation: Sham stimulation will be performed using electrodes placed on earlobe

groups.title: tVNS
groups.description:
This is the active stimulation arm of all participants.

Behavioral portions of the testing will then be carried out twice, with at least 72 hours between sessions (to avoid carryover effects).

Transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation: Non-invasive stimulation provided by transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation device at 20Hz, 100 μs pulse width

analyses.groupDescription:
A linear mixed effects model was conducted to account for carryover and order effects in this crossover trial.

Assuming α = 0.05, two-sided test, and 60 participants in total. If the carryover effect is negligible, we will have 90% power to detect an effect size of 0.604 for memory improvement

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Through study completion, an average of 1 month.

drug: transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation (tVNS) / transcutaneous auricular vagus nerve stimulation (taVNS)
explanation_target: Reason: The described intervention is transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation (tVNS/taVNS), a non‑invasive neuromodulation technique intended to improve cognition and quality of life in patients with amnestic MCI rather than a pharmacologic agent—so the aim is cognitive improvement. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act: Key details extracted — intervention names: tVNS / taVNS; modality: non‑invasive electrical stimulation of auricular vagal afferents; control: sham (earlobe) stimulation; intended effect: improve cognition / delay progression in MCI. This is a device/neuromodulation intervention, not a biologic or small molecule drug. citeturn0search0turn0search7

Web search results (selected, summarized): 1) Randomized clinical trial reporting cognitive benefit of taVNS in MCI (MoCA and memory measures improved vs sham). citeturn0search0 2) Meta‑analysis showing taVNS can modestly improve cognition (especially executive function) in healthy individuals, supporting cognitive‑enhancing effects. citeturn0search1 3) fMRI studies showing tVNS modulates salience, hippocampal and semantic networks relevant to AD/MCI (evidence of target engagement). citeturn0search3turn0search7 4) Synopsis/coverage noting clinical and mechanistic studies of taVNS in MCI and AD contexts. citeturn0search5

Reflect: Classification rationale — because the intervention is an electrical neuromodulation device applied to improve cognition/QOL in MCI (with sham control), it best fits the 'cognitive enhancer' category. It is not a biologic (e.g., antibody/vaccine) nor a small molecule targeting AD pathology, nor is the primary aim treatment of neuropsychiatric symptoms. Citations above support both the cognitive intent and non‑pharmacologic device nature. citeturn0search1turn0search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is transcutaneous vagal nerve stimulation (tVNS/taVNS), a non‑invasive electrical neuromodulation intended to improve cognition in amnestic MCI. Neuromodulation approaches like taVNS are generally aimed at altering network activity and enhancing synaptic plasticity and neuroprotective pathways rather than directly targeting amyloid, tau, inflammation, or other single molecular pathologies. Evidence shows taVNS can modestly improve cognition and is being tested in MCI. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Extracted details — intervention: transcutaneous (auricular) vagus nerve stimulation (tVNS/taVNS); modality: device-based, non‑invasive electrical stimulation of auricular vagal afferents with sham controls; intended effect: cognitive enhancement / delay progression in MCI. Because the primary mechanism and intent are to modulate neural circuits and enhance cognitive function (synaptic/network effects) rather than act on a specific molecular target (amyloid, tau, ApoE, etc.), the best CADRO match is M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection. Supporting trial and meta-analysis references: a double‑blind RCT reporting cognitive gains in MCI and a meta‑analysis showing modest cognitive benefits of taVNS. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Reflect: Verification — tVNS is a neuromodulatory device intervention (not a biologic or small molecule) whose intended therapeutic effect is cognitive enhancement via network/synaptic modulation. This aligns with CADRO M (Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection). It does not fit A (Amyloid) or B (Tau) because no amyloid/tau molecular targeting is described, nor is it purely diagnostic (exclude T) Other). Some studies show mixed or session‑dependent effects (e.g., single‑session null findings), so clinical efficacy is still under investigation, but the mechanistic class remains synaptic/neuroprotective. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Web search results (selected, summarized): 1) Meta‑analysis: taVNS improves overall cognitive performance (small effect), especially executive function. citeturn0search0 2) Double‑blind RCT in MCI reporting improved MoCA and memory measures after taVNS vs sham. citeturn0search1turn0search6 3) Single‑session randomized crossover trial in MCI found no benefit from a single tVNS session (shows effect may depend on dosing/schedule). citeturn0search2 4) Trials and protocols combining taVNS with other neuromodulation (rTMS) and mechanistic rationales describe bottom‑up modulation of brainstem‑limbic‑cortical pathways that can alter network function relevant to memory. citeturn0search5turn0search7
